cleaned_text: it really doesnt matter if you are satisfied or not what i said is deductively and hence objectively true its like disliking a mathematical proof when your intuitions do not match that it is the intuitions that need to be analyzed and corrected to be sensible again we are not talking about how practical it is but whether someone can claim that llms can impossibly be conscious as i demonstrated llms can be conscious assuming human brains are and physicalism holds etc hence the interesting discussion should shift from whether llms can be conscious to whether current llms are that is what we want to know and that has to make use of something about current llms vs what llms could be rather than just some flippant blanket statement note that i am not arguing that llms are conscious or will be conscious soon those are more things that would require the things you are looking for i am just giving the simple proof that the blanket dismissal is invalid and something more sensible is needed most of the points you make seem to be incorrect not true if we are not talking about sgd+common crawl then we are not talking about llms no that is not the definition of llms and does not even cover all llms that exist today i also explained how you can even get the property we wanted from sgd and its not like llms should be restricted to common crawl not true one shouldnt have to prove that all possible configurations of a very large language model cant have something equivalent to consciousness that is precisely what you need to do if you want to claim that llms cannot be conscious that is literally what the statement means not true arguing that our current methods of assembling those configurations are very unlikely to yield such one should be enough it depends on what statement you are making a lot of people are making a statement about what must be true for all llms not just for current llms if you want to make a statement about current llms then sure we can say that it is currently not simulating a human brain if you want to make a claim about whether llms could get there i dont think you have made a case for that the difference matters a lot for example because the methods can change i also already described a different process that is feasible it also is insufficient simulating a human brain is a sufficient way to argue that llms can be conscious provided we have ideal data however and this is important we also know that simulating a human brain may be sufficient to argue that an llm can be conscious however it is not a necessary property so just because current llms do not simulate a humnan brain you have not concluded that it is not conscious the implication only works in one direction not true if youve given that up as an argument then youve basically given up any argument that is relevant in the real world the exact opposite if you give up on valid logic then you give up on making any relevant argument if someone makes a general statement that applies both to a situation where the conclusion is true and a situation in which the situation is false then the argument has been proven incorrect if you are not familiar with logic you need to update that intuition it is fallacious and a very common method of rhetoric to use invalid arguments and then trying to rationalize away counterexamples in order to make a sound argument it has to make use of something that distinguishes situations where the conclusion is true from where it is false a blanket statement that llms cannot be conscious does not do that like i said before the whole point is to reject incorrect blanket conclusions and any sensible analysis must make use of the properties that hold for llms anything else is just people tricking themselves with bad reasoning it is also a rather telltale sign when people make bold statements and have not even bothered to define what they mean by consciousness some aspects of consciousness are not special at all and even bugs satisfy those properties people are generally rather confused about this topic

edelman distinguished between primary consciousness which came first in evolution and that humans share with other conscious animals and higher order consciousness which came to only humans with the acquisition of language a machine with only primary consciousness will probably have to come first what i find special about the tngs is the darwin series of automata created at the neurosciences institute by dr edelman and his colleagues in the <number>s and <number>s these machines perform in the real world not in a restricted simulated world and display convincing physical behavior indicative of higher psychological functions necessary for consciousness such as perceptual categorization memory and learning they are based on realistic models of the parts of the biological brain that the theory claims subserve these functions the extended tngs allows for the emergence of consciousness based only on further evolutionary development of the brain areas responsible for these functions in a parsimonious way no other research ive encountered is anywhere near as convincing i post because on almost every video and article about the brain and consciousness that i encounter the your company or business synthetic data could be better than real data <url> example of this improving llama <number> llm <url> boosting visuallanguage models with synthetic captions and image embeddings <url> >our method employs pretrained texttoimage model to synthesize image embeddings from captions generated by an llm despite the texttoimage model and vlm initially being trained on the same data our approach leverages the image generators ability to create novel compositions resulting in synthetic image embeddings that expand beyond the limitations of the original dataset extensive experiments demonstrate that our vlm finetuned on synthetic data achieves comparable performance to models trained solely on humanannotated data while requiring significantly less data furthermore we perform a set of analyses on captions which reveals that semantic diversity and balance are key aspects for better downstream performance finally we show that synthesizing images in the image embedding space is <number> faster than in the pixel space we believe our work not only addresses a significant challenge in vlm training but also opens up promising avenues for the development of selfimproving multimodal models simulations transfer very well to real life <url> study on quality of synthetic data <url> >we systematically investigate whether synthetic data from current stateoftheart texttoimage generation models are readily applicable for image recognition our extensive experiments demonstrate that synthetic data are beneficial for classifier learning in zeroshot and fewshot recognition bringing significant performance boosts and yielding new stateoftheart performance further current synthetic data show strong potential for model pretraining even surpassing the standard imagenet pretraining we also point out limitations and bottlenecks for applying synthetic data for image recognition hoping to arouse more future research in this direction scaling
